>
Of the sense and right exposition of the worde of God, and by what
maner of meanes it may be expounded.

Early beloved bre
thren, I doe un
derstande, that by
I meanes of my do
ctrine of the worde
of God, ther are ri
sen sadry thoughts
in the hearts of many men, yea, and
that of some there are sowen abroade
very ungodly speches. For some there
are, which doe suppose, that the scrip
tures, that is, the verie word of God,
is of it selfe so darke, that it cannot bee
read with any profit at al. And againe
some other affirme, that the worde
plainly delivered by God to mankind,
doth stand in neede of no exposition.
And therefore, say they, that the scrip
tures ought in deede to be reade of all
men, but so, that every man may law
fully inuent and choose to himself such
a sense, as everie one shall be perswa
ded in himelfe to be most convenient.
These fellowes doe altogether con
denine the order received of the Chur
ches, whereby the minister of ye church
doth expounde the Scriptures to the
congregation.

But I (deerely beloved)
it as yee have begun, so ye will goe for
warde to pray to the Lorde, doe trust
by the hope that I have in Gods good
nesse, that I am able plainely to de
clare, that to the godly the scripture is
nothing darke at al, & that the lord his
will is altogether to have us under
stande it. Then that the Scriptures
ought always to be expouded. Where
also I will teach you the manner, and
some readie waies howe to interprete
the Scriptures. The handling of these
pointes shall take away the impedi
ments which drive men from the rea
ding of the word of god, and shall cause
the reading and hearing of the word of
God to be both wholesome & fruittull.

And first of all, that Gods will is,
to have his word understoode of man
kinde, we may thereby gather especi
ally, because ye in speaking to his ser
vants, hee used a most common kinde
of speech, wherewithall even the verie
idiots were acquainted. Neither doe
we reade, that the Prophets and Apo
stles the seruants of God, and inter
preters of his high and everlasting
wisedome, did use any strange kinde
of speach: so that in the whole packe of
writers, none can be founde to excell
them in a more plaine and easie phrase
of writing. Their writings are full of
common proverbs, similitudes, para
bles, comparisons, devised narratios,
examples, and such other like manner
of speeches, tha which there is nothing
that doth more moove & plainely teach
the common fortes of wittes among
mortall men. Ther ariseth, I con
fesse, some darkenesse in the scriptures
by reason of the naturall propertie, fi
gurative ornamentes, and the unac
quainted use of the tongues. But that
difficultie may easily be helped by stu
die diligence, faith, and the meanes of
skilfull interpreters,

I knowyy Apo
stle Peter saith in ye epistles of Paule,
Manie thinges are hard to be under
stoode. But immediately he addeth,
which the unlearned, and those that
are unperfect or unstable, pervert, as
they doe the other Scriptures also
unto their owne destruction. There
by we gather, that the scripture is dif
ficult or obscure to the unlearned,
unskilfull, unerercised, and malicious
or corrupted wils, and not to the zea
lous and godlie readers or hearers
thereof.

Therefore, when saint Paul
saith, If as yet our Gospell be hidde:
from them it is hidde which perish, in
whome the Prince of this worlde hath
blinded the understanding of the un
beleevers, that to them there shoulde
not shine the light of the vospell of
the glorie of Christ, who is the image
of God. Hee doeth not lay the blame
of this difficultie on the word of God,
but upon the unprofitable hearers.
Thosoever wee are therefore, that do
desire rightly to understand the worde
of God, our care must be, that Satan
possesse not our mindes, & close up our
eies.

For, our saviour also in the
gospell saide, This is damnation, be
cause the light came into the worlde,
and men loved darkenesse rather than
light. Besides that, the holy Pro
phets of God, and the Apostles, did
not call the worde of God or the scrip
tures darkenesse, obscurenesse, or mi
stinesse, but a certaine brightnesse and
lightsomnesse. David saith, Thy word
is a lanterne unto my feete, and a
light unto my pathes. And what I
pray you is more evident than that
which in making doubtfull and ob
scure thinges manifest, no man doeth
referre to darkenesse and uncertaine
ties: Things uncertaine, doubtfull and
obscure are made manifest by those
things that are more certaine, sure and
evident. But as often as anie duestion
or controversie doth happen in mat
ters of faith, doe not all men agree
that it ought to bee ended and deter
mined by the Scriptures? it must there
fore needes be that the Scriptures are
evident, plaine, and most alluredly cer
taine.

But though the scripture be mani
fest, and the worde of God be evident,
yet notwithstanding, it refuseth not a
godly or holie exposition, but rather an
holy exposition doth give a setting out
to the worde of God, & bringeth foorth
much fruite in the godlie hearer. And
forbicause many do deny, that the scri
ptures ought to have any exposition, I
wil shew by examples (which can not
be gainesayde) that they ought altoge
ther to bee expounded. For God him
elfe, having often comunication with
Moses by the space of fortie daies, and
as many yeres, did by Moses expound
to the Church the wordes of the lawe,
which he spake in mount Sina to the
whole congregation of Israel, wri
ting them in two tables, which Moses
left to us, the Deuteronomie and cer
taine other bookes as commentaries
upon Gods commaundements.

After
that immediately followed the Pro
phets, who interpreting the lawe of
Moses did applie it to the times, pla
ces, and men of their age, and left to
us that follow, their sermons as plaine
expositions of Gods law. In the eight
Chapter of Nehemias we reade these
wordes. Esdras the Priell brought in
the Lawe, the booke of Moses, and
stoode upon a turret made of woode
that is in the holie pulpit. And Esdras
opened the booke before the congre
gation of men and women, and who
soever else had any understanding
And the Levites sloode with him, so
that hee reade out of the booke, and
y Levites instructed the people in the
law, et the people stood in their place,
and they reade in the booke of the
lawe distinetly, expounding the sense
and causing them to understande the
reading. Thus much in the booke of
Nehemias. Marke heare by the way
(my brethren) that the lawfull and
holy ministers of the Church of God,
did not onely reade the worde of God,
but did also expound it.

This manner of reading and ex
pounding the Scriptures or worde
of God, our Lorde Jesus Christ did
neither abrogate nor contemne, when
comming in the fleshe, he did as a true
Prophete and heavenly maister in
struct the people of his Church, in
the doctrine of the newe Testament.
For entring into the Synagogue at
Nazareth, he stoode up to reade : and
there was delivered to him the booke
of the prophet Elaye. So hee opened
the booke, and reade a certaine notalbe
place out of the lxi. Chapter. Then
shutting the booke, hee gave it to the
Minister againe, and expounded that
which he had read, declaring how that
in himselfe nowe that prophesie was
fulfilled.

Moreover after that hee was risen
from death he joyned himelfe in com
panie to the two Disciples, which
went to Emaus, with whome he tal
ked of sundrie matters: but at length
beginning at Moses and all the pro
phetes, he expounded to them what so
ever was written of himself through
out all the Scriptures. The Apostles
following this example of the Lorde,
did theselves also erpound the word
of God.

For Peter in the seconde Chap
ter of the Actes of the Apostles, doth
expounde the rui. Psalme of Christ
his resurrection from the dead. And
Philip also doeth plainely exounde to
the noble man of Ethiope the prophe
sie of Clay, wherby he bringeth him to
the faith of Christ, and fellowship of
the Church. Whosoever doth say that
Paul doth not every where interpret
the holy Scripture, hee hath neyther
read nor seene the deedes nor writings
of Paule. Thus have I, I hope, both
plainely & substantially shewed, that ye
word of God ought to be expounded.

And for those which cry out against
the exposition of the Scriptures, and
woulde not have the ministers of the
worde and Churches, to declare the
scriptures in open and solemne audi
ence, neyther to apply them to the pla
ces, times, states, & persons, their fetch
is to seeke somewhat else than the ho
nour due unto God. They leade their
lives farre otherwise, than is comely
for godly men. Their talke is wicked,
unseemly, & dishonest. Their deeds are
mischievous, and haynous offences,
And this woulde they to doe without
punishment, and therefore desire to
have the exposition of the Scriptures
to be taken cleane away:

For if a man
doe read the wordes of the Scripture
onely, not applying it to the states,
places, times and persons, it seemeth
that he hath not greatly touched their
ungodly and wicked life. Therefore,
when they crye that Sermons and ex
positions of the scriptures, ought to be
taken awaye from among men, and
that the Scriptures ought to be reade
simplie without anie addition, they
minde nothing else but to cast behinds
them the lawe of God, to treade under
foote all discipline and rebuking of
sinne, and so to offende freelie without
punishment : which fort of men the
righteous Lorde wil in his appointed
time punish, so much the inore grie
vously, as they doe more boldly rebell
against their God.

In the meane season, all the mini
sters of the Church must beware,
that they followe not herein their
owne affections anie whit at all, or
else corrupt the Scriptures by their
wrong interpretations, and so by that
meanes set foorth to the Church their
owne inventions, and not the word of
God. Some such like offence it seemeth
that the teachers of the auncient peo
ple in olde time did commit, because
the Lord in Ezekiell accuseth them
saying: Seemeth it a smal thing to you
to have eaten up the good pasture, but
that ye must also tread the residue of
your pasture under your feeter and to
drinke the clearer water, but that ye
must trouble the rest with your feeter
Thus mie sheepe must be faine to eate
the thing that is troden downe with
your feete, and to drinke that which
yee with your feete have desiled.

A
fore offence is this, which the Lorde
according to his justice punisheth most
sharpelie. Te therefore the interpre
ters of Gods holy worde, and faithfull
ministers of the Church of Christ,
must have a diligent regarde to keepe
the Scriptures found and perfect, and
to teach the people of Christ the worde
of God sincerely, made plaine I mean,
and not corrupted or darkened by foo
lish and wrong expositions of our
owne invention.

And nowe (dearely beloved) the
place and time require us to say som
what unto you, touching the interpre
tation of the holy Scriptures, or the
exposition of the worde of God. Wher
in I will not speake anie thing parti
cularly, of the skilfull knowledge of
tongues, or the liberall sciences, which
are things requisite in a good inter
preter, but will briefly touch the ge
neralities alone.

And first of al ye must
understande, that some thinges in the
Scriptures or worde of God, are so
plainely set foorth, that they have neede
of no interpretation, neither will ad
mit any exposition. Which if any man
goe about with his owne expositions
to make more manifest, he may seeme
to do as wittily, as he which with fag
got light and torches, would helpe the
sunne at his rising to give more light
unto the worlde.

As for those thinges
which are so set down, that they seeme
to require our helpe to erpound them,
they must not be interpreted after our
owne fantasies, but according to the
minde and meaning of him, by whome
the Scriptures were revealed. For
Saint Peter sayeth. The prophesie
came not in old time by the will of
man: but holie men of God spake as
they were moved bie the holie Ghost.

Therefore the true and proper sense
of Gods worde must bee taken out of
the Scriptures theselves, and not
be forceably thrust upon the Scrip
tures as we our selves lust. And there
withall ye must marke a few certaine
rules which I meane briefly to touche
and to shewe unto you, in those fewe
wordes which I have yet to speake.

First since the Apostle Paul would
have the exposition of the Scriptures
to agree fitly, and in everie point pro
portionally with our faith: as it is to
bee seene in the twelfch to the Ro
manes: And because againe in the la
ter epistle to the Corinthians he saith,
Seeing then that we have the same spi
rite of faith saccording as it is writ
ten, I beleeved and therfore have I
spoken) we also beleeve and therefore
doe we speake: Let it therefore be ta
ken for a point of Catholike religion,
not to bring in, or admit anie thing in
our expositions, which others have al
ledged against the received articles of
our faith, conteyned in the Apostles
Creede, and other cofessions of the an
ctient fathers.

For sayth the Apostle,
In defence of the trueth we can saie
somwhat, but against the trueth we
are able to say nothing. When there
fore in the Gospell after S. John wee
read ye saying of ye Lorde, The father is
greater than l, we must thinke that it
is against the articles of our fayth
to make or admit any equalitie in the
Godhead betwirt the Father and the
Sonne : and therefore that the Lorde
his meaning was otherwise than the
very wordes at the first blush do seeme
to import. Againe, when we reade this
saying of the apostle, It can not be that
they which were once illuminated, if
they fal awaie should be renved agaive
into repetance: Let us not beleeve that
repentance is to be denied to the that
fall. For the Catholike Faith is this,
that in every place, at every season, so
long as wee live on this earth a full
pardon of all sinnes is promised to all
men which turne to the Lorde. In
like manner when we reade that the
Lorde tooke breade, and sayde of the
breade, This is my bodie, let us pre
sently rememder that the articles of
our faith doe attribute to our Lorde
the verie body of a ma, which ascended
into heaven, and fitteth at the right
hande of the Father, from whence it
shall come to judge the quicke and the
dead,

and let us thinke that the Lorde
speaking of the Sacrament, woulde
have us to erpound the wordes of the
Sacrament Sacramentally, and not
Transubstantially. Also in reading
that saying of the Apostle, Flesh and
bloud can not inherite the kingdome
of God, let us not by and by uppon
these wordes take it simply as the
words do seeme to signifie, but sticking
to the Article of our faith, I beleeve
the resurrection of the bodie, let us
understande that by flesh and bloude
are ment ye affectios & infirmities, not
the nature & substance of our bodies.

Furthermore, we reade in the gos
pell, that the Lorde doth gather a sum
of the lawe and the Prophets, saying:
Thou shalt love the Lord thy God
with all thy heart, with all thy soule,
and with all thy mind, this is the chiefe
and great commaundement. And the
second is like unto it, Thou shalt love
thy neighbour as thy solfe In these two
commaundements. keigeth the whole
lawe and the Prophets, Matth. 22. Ap
on these wordes of hte Lord, that holy
man Aurelius Augustinus in the 16.
Chapter of his first booke De dostrins
Cbrist, saieth: whosoever doth seeme
to himself to understad the holy scri
ptures, or any part thereof, so that that
understanding he doeth not worke
these two points of charitie towards
God, &t his neighbour, he yet doth not
understand the scriptures perfeetly.
But whosoever shall take out of them
such an opinion as is profitable to the
working of this charitie, and yet shall
not say y selfe same thing which shalbe
proved that he did meane who me he
readeth in that place, that ma doth not
erre to his owne destruction, nor doth
altogether by lying deceive other me:
Thus much writ Augustin.

We must
therefore by all meanes possible, take
heede that our interpretations doe not
tende to the overthrow of charitie, but
to the furtherance and commendation
of it to all men. The Lord sayth, Strive
not with the wicked. But if wee af
firme that he spake this to the Magi
strates also, the shall charitie towards
our neighbours, the safetie of them
that are in jeopardie, and defece of the
oppressed, be broken and cleane taken
away. For theeves & unruly persons,
robbers and naughtie fellowes, will
oppresse the widowes, the fatherlesse,
and the poore, so that all iniquitie shall
reigne and have the upper hande.
But in a matter so manifestly know
en, I suppose it is not needefull to use
many examples.

Moreover, it is requifite in expoun
ding the Scriptures, and searching
out the true sense of Gods worde, that
we marke upon what occasion everie
thing is spoken, what goeth before,
what followeth after, at what season,
in what order, and of what person any
thing is spoken.

By the occasion, and
the sentences going before and com
ming after, are eramples and para
bles for the most part erpounded.
Also, unlesse a man do alwaies marke
the manner of speaking throughout
the whole Scriptures, and that verie
diligently too, hee can not choose in his
expositions but erre verie much out of
the right way.

Saint Paul observing the circum
stance of the time, did thereby con
clude that Abraham was justified nei
ther by Circumcision, nor yet by the
Lawe. The places are to be seene in
the fourth to the Romanes, and the
thirde to the Galathians:

Againe,
when it is sayde to Peter, Put up thy
sworde into thy sheath, He that taketh
the sword shall perish with the sword:
Wee must consider that Peter bare
the personage of an Apostle, and not
of a Magistrate. For of the Magi
strate wee reade, that to him is given
the sworde to revengement. But it
woulde bee over tedious and too trou
blesome, to rehearse more examples of
every particular place.

There is also heside these, another
manner of interpreting of the word of
God, that is, by conferring together
and by expounding the darker by the
more evident, and the fewer by the
the places which are like or unlike,
more in number. Whereas therefore
the Lorde saieth, The father is greater
than l, we must consider that the same
Lorde in an other place saieth, My fa
ther and l are all one.

And whereas
James the Apostle sayth, That Abra
ham and wee are justified by workes,
there are many places in Saint Paul
to be set against that one. And this
manner of interpreting did Peter the
Apostle allowe, where he saith: Wee
have a right sure worde of prophesie,
whereunto if ye attend, as unto a light
that shineth in a darke place, yee doe
well, unto the day dawne, and the day
starre arise in your heartes.

That aunctient writer Tertullian
affirmeth, that they are heretiques,
and not men of the right faith, which
drawe some odde thinges out of the
Scriptures to their owne purpose, not
having anie respeet to the rest. But
doe by that meanes picke out unto
themselnes a certaine fewe testimo
nies which they woulde have altoge
ther to be beleeved, the whole Scrip
ture in the meane season gainesay
ing it, because in deede the fewer
places must bee understood accor
ding to the meaning of the more in
number.

And finally, the most effectuall
rule of all, whereby to erpounde the
worde of God, is an heart that lo
veth God and his glorie, not puffed
up with pride, not desirous of vaine
glorie, not corrupted with heresies
and evill affections: but which doth
continually pray to God for his holy
spirite, that as by it the scripture was
revealed and inspired, so also by the
same spirite, it may bee expounded to
the glorie of God and safegarde of the
faithfull.

Let the minde of the interpreter
be set on fire with zeale to advaunce
vertue and with hatred of wickednesse
even to the suppressing therof. Let not
ye heart of such an expositor cal to coun
sel that subtile sophister the devil, least
peradventure nowe also he do corrupt
the sense of Gods worde, as heretofore
he did in Paradise. Let him not abide
to heare mans wisdome argue directly
gainst the worde of God. This if the
good & faithfull expositor of gods word
shal do, then although in some pointes
he do not (as the proverbe saith) hit the
very head of the nayle, in the darker
sense of the Scripture : yet not with
standing, that errour ought not to bee
condened for an heresie in the author,
nor judged hurtfull unto the hearer
And whosoever shall bring the darker,
and more proper meaning of ye Scrip
tnre to light, he shal not by and by con
demne the unperfect exposition of that
other: no more than he which is anthor
of the unperfect exposition, shall reiecte
the more proper sense of the better er
positour, but by acknowledging it shal
receive it with thanks giving.

Thus much hitherto have I saide
touthing the sense and exposition of
Gods word: which as GOD revealed
it to men, so also hee would have them
in any case to understand it. There
fore there is no cause for anye man by
reason of a few difficulties, to dispaire
to attaine to the true understandinge
of the Scriptures. The Scripture
doth admit a godly and religious in
terpretation. The worde of God is a
rule for all men and ages to leade
their lives by: Therefore ought it
by interpretation to be applyed to all
ages and men of all fortes. For even
our God himelfe did by Mosas in ma
ny wordes expounde and applye to his
people the lawe, which he gave & pub
lished in mount Sina. Furthermore,
it was a solempne use among the aun
cient Prophets, first to read, and then
by expositious to applye Gods lawe to
the people. Our Lord Jesus Christ him
selfe expounded the Scriptures. The
same did the Apostles also. The worde
of God therefore ought to be expoun
ded: as for those which would not have
it exposided their meaning is, because
they would sinne freely, without con
trolling or punishment. But whereas
the scripture dooth admit an expositio,
it doth not yet admit any exposition
whatsoever For that which savoureth
of mans imagination it utterly rejec
teth. For as by ye spirit of god ye scrip
ture was revealed, so by ye same spirit
it is requisite to expound it.

Ther are
therefore certaine rules, to expound y
worde of God religiously, by the verye
word of God it selfe : that is, so to ex
pound it, that the exposition disagree
not with the articles of our faith, nor
be contrarie to charitie towards God
and our neighbour: but that it be tho
roughly surueyed, and grounded upon
that which went before and followeth
after, by diligent weighing of all the
circustances, and laying together of
the places. And chiefely it is requisite,
that ye heart of the interpreter be god
ly bent, willing to plant vertue, and
plucke up vice by the rootes, and final
ly alwayes ready evermore to pray to
the Lord, that he will bouchsafe to il
luminate our minds, that Gods name
may in all things be glorified. For his
is the glory, honour, and dominion, for
ever and ever. Amen.
